There is no rhyme or reason as to why the Avengers would give a flying crap about a woman who died in the crossfire. Would they be sad? Yes. Would they be guilt ridden? Yes. Would they take her children into Avenger's Mansion? NO! Would they make a statue honoring the woman? NO! Should Chuck Austen never work in comics again? YES! And the art is shitty too. Just a few more months till Bendis... Rating: F

Plot: Superman's a vampire and the JLA is fighting a devil cult or something. Review: I've been buying it for this Claremont! and Byrne! run, but I haven't read it. Because it's been absolute shit. Sorry, can't put it any more eloquently than that. Rating: F

Plot: A wrap-up to the 'Hollywood' storyline and all about Peter Parker. Review: This issue proves once again how much Bendis must hate, HATE, secret identities. Mary Jane knows. Doc Ock knows. The Green Goblin knows. The Green Golbin's kid knows. SHIELD knows. The Ultimates know. And now Gwen Stacy knows. I'm was starting to lose that feeling of suspended disbelief and then this happens: So it's Gwen, Peter, and Mary Jane all chilling on Spider-man's bed, and Peter doesn't have one thought about the possible "ramifications" of that. That killed me. He lives with a hot girl. He dates a hot girl. They both know he is a SUPERHERO and there is not one thought balloon about hanky-panky? Did that spider bite chemically castrate him as well? Next Issue: Carnage. Whoop-de-freakin-do! Rating: C+

Plot: Bats, Supes, and Wondy try to figure out what to do with Kara Zor-El, Kal-El's cousin. Or is she... Review: Okay we get it Michael Turner, you can draw hot chicks. Staged where ever it is the Amazons live, The Holy Trinity of the DCU get ambushed by a bunch of Dommsday clones. Yes, that Doomsday. Batman and Wonder Woman are paranoid, Superman is over-protective, and at the end, it is off to Apkolips to face Darkseid. Lots of Amazonian ass shots, and wide eyed blonde chicks. Other than that, nothing that couldn't have been done in the previous issues. Stretching out this storyline to make plenty of room for Michael Turner's artwork has made a weak premise weaker, and further leads me to the conclusion that NO ONE knows what to do with Superman mythos lately. Rating: D+

Plot: Alcatraz reopens for super-villians, and two of them aren't showing up right, but mostly an administrative issue for the team. Review: And by administrative, I mean status quo. Arsenal's benefactor shows up, shrouded in mystery. Metamorpho 2.0 changes into Shift (not bad). Huntress leaves and warns Arsenal about Nightwing's emotional intrest in the team. Two robots explode. But it works. Winick proves once again how hip he is by dropping smart, witty dialouge in a script that feels action packed, but kind of isn't at the same time. The art, however, while effectively telling the story, is ugly and muddled, and lacks the polish of the previous artist. The book really isn't about high emotional drama, a change from most teambooks. It has personnel drama, but it is mostly about action and funny one-liners. It reminds me of TV's Angel in that respect. When something big happens, it is BIG. But for the most part, it's about whupping ass. Rating: B+

Plot: Get Raven out of Brother Blood's fortress, and watch out for Deathstroke and his daughter. Review: I was really hyped by the new Teen Titans, and I have really liked every issue of the relaunch... except this one. Actually, this whole "Get Raven" storyline has left me sour, as it is set deep in DC Comics mythology, that frankly, I don't know very much about. Every single time I see a Brother Blood story, they are rebuilt to the particular writers wishes, so I really can't see why the revelations about the cult here actually matter. The former Young Justice half of the Titans are left to the back burner here, save Robin (Tim Drake), and with the deep backstory between the Titans, Deathstroke, Deathstroke's kids, Raven, Starfire, and Garth (who looks silly when in non-animal form) it was hard to really care about what was going on. Plus, when they do highlight Robin, he says things like, "Normally I wouldn't hit someone younger than me, but you really need a spanking." Ugh. Rating: C-

Plot: "Cops" meets X-Men starring future cop mutant Bishop. Review: I've always dug Bishop, and I'm happy to see a gimmick for him that will actually work. This issue, however, stars Ismael, the human who gets assigned to work with Bishop as they go through the streets of District X, a mutant ghetto in Manhattan. Ismael is originally paired with your standard minority hating cop Gus, who isn't exactly thrilled with working in District X, and considers it a place of trash and mutant excrement. Ismael seems a bit more compassionate, albeit, to a fault, when he helps cover up when his partner Gus screws up a domestic abuse call. David Hine and David Yardin set an effective pace and style in the book, saving the superhero money shot for the last page. This first issue has really set my expectations high for this book, and I can't wait to see if someone is actually able to make Bishop cool again. Rating: B+

Plot: Tim Drake gives up the mantle of Robin. The Spoiler becomes new Robin. Review: First of all, I love Tim Drake, so the idea of him NOT being Robin bothers me. But Bill Willingham is a good writer, and he has included Tim into the pages of this book, while the new Robin wears the red, gold, and green. I haven't read this book in years, and when I had stopped, the Spoiler wasn't so... childish. She was pregnant and had had a baby, so seeing her act very "girly-girl" was very surprising. This launching point for the title introduces new penciler Damion Scott, who despite a few layout hiccups here and there, certainly impresses with clean and cartoony artwork. But like I said, I love Tim Drake, and so this will be a tough sell to me in future issues. And it is not even mentioned how the new "civilian" Tim Drake is going to handle The Teen Titans either, which is a DC flagship right now. This is a major detail, and it hurt my opinion of the book. Rating: B

Plot: The origin continues for Jason Rusch as he struggles with the local Detroit hoods, and the abilities of Firestorm. Review: Pretty interesting stuff. I don't have a lot of interest invested in the Firestorm character, so the changes in persona and powers don't really tie me up in bunches, and it is all pretty fun. From what I know of the old Firestorm, it was a form that was shared between a codgy old professor and some random teenager. Now, it looks like the powers will be shared with Jason, and whoever happens to be next to him. Luckily, a little to luckily for suspension of disbelief's sake, the unintended partner forgets all that has happened. I am interested in what has become of the old Firestorm, and how exactly these powers ended up in front of a barn in Detroit, but so far nothing on that. I've been a fan of CrissCross's work since the ill-fated Slingers, and I am happy to see him work on something promising again. Props to DC for letting them take a fan favorite like this and A) Completely rewriting him from the ground up, and B) Making him black. When this origin arc ends, I want to see if they will keep the character in Detroit, and how exactly the characterize the city. A great start so far. Rating: B+

Plot: First issue of the Joss Whedon era of the X-men. The roster drops to five as Scott Summers resolves to make the team a bonafide super team, complete with colorful spandex. Review: I'm digging it all so far, but then again, I've got a man-crush on Joss Whedon's work, and I am developing another crush on john Cassaday's work too. It is a return to some older ideas about the X-men. Scott vs. Logan, a mutant cure, Kitty Pryde, and the Danger Room all return to the spotlight, but with the added bonus of witty dialogue, great characterization, and some fantastic artwork. My favorite part? "Superpowers, a scintillating wit, and the best body money can buy... and I still rate below a corpse." -The White Queen Rating: A-

Plot: The Invaders recruit Namor. Hawkey and Wasp knock boots. Review: Dear God, make it stop. Just two more issues to Bendis... Just two more issues to Bendis... Just two more issues to Bendis... Rating: F

Plot: Part one in a series that will bring about the Ultimate version of Carnage. While Bendis stretches out the eventual reveal of Carnage, Spider-man visits yet another person who knows who he really is, Dr. Curt Conners. Review: In what is becoming more and more formulaic in Ultimate Spider-man new villains, we don't actually see the thing, just a vague set-up. We do get to see the first steps of Dr. Conners inevitable breakdown, but whether or not he becomes Carnage is yet to be seen. I never really liked Carnage, however, so I hope this isn't as drug out as the last arc. The art? Bagley shines as always. Rating: B-

Plot: Still in the first arc, we find out what Kiden was up to the past few months. And that the girl who may or not be Wolverine's daughter didn't kill that guy. Review: After waiting ump-teen months for a new release from this promising title, I must say how utterly disappointed I am with this issue. Very little happened. I mean, nothing happened. Two girls sat in a diner, and listened to a third girl talk about being homeless. But God does it look fantastic. Middleton suffers from incredible talent that just cannot be rushed, and should not be substituted. But the story has got to back up the wait, and this issue was lacking one. It'll fit in okay when this first arc is packed into a graphic novel, but on its own it falls flat. A shame, because I really like the concept for the book. Rating: C-

Plot: JLA vs. Vampires? Review: Well, we have finally came to the conclusion of 'The Tenth Circle' which has really been a demonstration of how far comics and its creators have come. I know these little throwbacks to old creators please alot of the older fans, who mistakingly believe that the 'Dark Phoenix Saga' is the greastest stroy ever told, but to me, its pure annoyance. The JLA was created to be the action title for DC; a place for the best and brightest in the DCU to whoop-ass, save the day, and look pretty as hell doing it. For a team that that has bested white martians, Starro, and a host of other big bads, a few vampires seem a little too small fry. Plus, nobody looked pretty doing it. A spectacular faliure to hold my intrest, the final issue of this Claremont, Byrne, and Ordway proved once again how archic the comics of old can be, and why we must constantly push for this industry to try new things, and forget the ways of old. P.S. There was a huge error in this issue in the coloring department. Check it out! Rating: F

T'Challa End of an era. At least for me... Yesterday, Shannon got off work early, and went to the comic book store while waiting for me to get off the clock at my job. She brought home a few of our monthlies, and one of those books was Black Panther #62. The last issue of the one book that kept me into comics. I can't really produce why I wanted out of comics in the first place. It was around the time when urlLink Marvel was bouncing back bankruptcy. New blood was flooding into Marvel, with stacks of new, fresh, and exciting ideas. And I had had enough of them. Nothing was really getting me excited about comics; my current stack of monthlies was undergoing creative changes that almost all sucked. Not in the fanboy, "They changed the costume! Worst comic ever," but in the, "Wow, this sucks," kind of way. Marvel Knight hit and I was into Smith's Daredevil, and nothing much else. But I was turned onto Black Panther by a friend who said it was great and fell in love. Within the first page, I realized that urlLink Priest was writing this book, who wrote another favorite of mine, Quantum and Woody. So for awhile, everyone I knew was reading Black Panther, until issue 6. Then the book got difficult to read. My friends were confused, I was confused, I think all the fill-in artists were confused because the book was a hodge-podge of bizarre story-telling techniques. Mike Manley, one time artist of Darkhawk, really sucked, and a lot of people jumped ship. I didn't. I read, and reread the storyline, Enemy of the State, because it was fantastic. I HAD to understand it. I HAD to get all of the references. I HAD to get all of the jokes. And I never let the book go again. But I'm in the minority. Sales slumped and the book is officaily cancelled. Of course, there is the Crew, but that’s another story. But much like the other big cancellations in my life, Darkhawk, New Warriors, Quantum and Woody, a monthly inspiration for me is gone. I think about writing comics all of the time, and every time I have an idea I compare it to the great-ness those books have risen to in my mind. But inspiration sometimes fail me, and what worries me about this cancellation of a comic book, comes the fear that a cancellation of my creativity may go with it. I still have all of my dreams and hopes I entered adulthood with, but now I have reasons why they can't happen. Why they wouldn't happen. Why they shouldn't happen. My fears no longer exist only in conversations over coffee, but in subconscious failure techniques that are bound to bloom once more as another semester of higher education looms. Long live T'Challa...

A rant of political ideas I'm turning this essay in tomorrow for my comparitice politics course. The professor wanted to know our political beliefs. Values, ideologies, beliefs, mores, and prejudices. No political scientist should leave home without them. They represent the opinions, experiences, and criticisms that people have learned, taught, and created for themselves. Each word can carry a thousand different snapshots in time where a person understood something for a moment. A moment where all the confusion, ignorance, and fear were swept away and all that remained were simply truths, or at the very least perceived truths. For the purpose of organization, label these values, ideologies, beliefs, mores and prejudices into categories. It is doubtful, however, that any one person can fit all of their snapshots into the categories. That is why this paper isn’t titled “Tuesdays with Clinton” or “What Would Bill O’Reilly Do”. I have too many pictures. Although, the left box is much fuller than the right box. My lean towards the left side of politics comes from being a middle class kid with working class parents. They weren’t active in politics or even aware of politics, but the TV always stayed on the channel longer if a Kennedy was on the screen. When I was younger, being a democrat, or on the left was much easier. It was all about helping people. These people are poor and need money, and if other people were saying we shouldn’t give it to them, they seemed cruel and mean. The first thing taught in kindergarten is the ability to share. As age and education start to grow, the ability to back-up those impulses to help people become harder. Not everyone deserves help in everyone eyes. That’s when the arguments start and you realize that you have much to learn. Too much to learn. “What have you learned so far?” is what you’re asking me. I’ve learned that white people are still very afraid of black people. I’ve learned that the separation of church and state will be a constant battle. Ditto for abortion. I’ve learned that feminism has many different meanings, from bra burning, to achieving untold success in a man’s world, and somehow, feminism can mean flashing breasts for beads at a festival. I’ve learned that even the victims of genocide are willing to burn books. I don’t believe in being color-blind. When a person is color blind, they can still see the world, just skewed a little. Racism is still here. The past forty years on non-legislated segregation is just a drop in the bucket compared to centuries of violence and intolerance. White people seem to think that just because the drinking fountains are open to everyone that that somehow erases generations of pain and angst. Black folk have taken their labels and used them to empower themselves, and now they just want a fair shot, and for some unimaginable reason that scares the hell out of white people. White people claim to believe in an American Dream, or a melting pot. Nevertheless, every time a minority gets a step forward, there is cadre of white people there trying to knock them back a few steps. They use bibles against homosexuals. They use the “not my ancestors” excuse. They use acts of government to watch them attend their mosque. They use “research” to make women feel guilty about becoming professionals and not staying at home to raise babies. They use racial profiling. They use words like abomination, will of god, and “for the children” to try to keep their piles of money and land safe. One of the smaller tragedies of 9/11 is that my generation is longer referred to as the first in U.S. history that may do worse financially than its parents. We are now the 9/11 generation. The “Shock and Awe” generation. The War Against Terrorism generation. Does my upcoming bachelor’s degree mean anymore than a diploma these days? R.I.P. Kurt Cobain. Here's my rant on Kurt's death. He overdosed in Europe on heroin, which was the proverbial cry for help. He was sent back the states, and was all alone. His wife should have been there, or a band member, or someone who considered him a friend. It's called a suicide watch people, and those close to him screwed the pooch on that one. Here's my rant on his life. Five years ago, hell, two years ago, I would have gone on and on about how overrated Kurt was. I would have bitched about his status as rock deity was the by-product of overzealous critics and Gen-xers, including myself, and his impact was too early lost in a wash of pop-punk, cookie cutter rap music, and teenie pop. A song, nearly ten years old, ripped through radio and almost performed the same trick "Smells Like Teen Spirit" did when it killed pop rock and hair bands. Music execs must have been relieved when Nirvana died. They could restart the same techniques that lined their pockets for years, without the nucisance of people trying to break the mold. No more ticketmaster lawsuits. No more money spent on musicians who may not sell stratosphere numbers. Yes, there are exceptions today, but there are few and far between in corporate controlled radio playlists, and the cloneing of hip-artists, emo bands, and teen friendly marketing gimmicks. Why is Kurt important? Awesome songs, awesome spirit. "Let me die before I become Pete Townsend." that's some rock star shit! His impact IS large, but mostly because it was a time in music where it felt, even the slightest bit, that it was in the listeners hands. Clear Channel nixed an anti-war group’s proposed message on one of its NYC billboards citing it was distasteful to the community. Foul some will say, but there is nothing that can be done about it. It's privately owned by CC, not by the city, therefore, 1st Amendment rules do not apply. Clear Channel is also responsible for that Dixie Chicks flap last year, as well as the canceling of Howard Stern in six radio markets this year. A billboard against the war, a pop group against the war, a shock jock against the war... all thrashed by a company that owns over 1000 different radio stations across the country. When the FCC decided to nix its policies of disallowing media companies like Clear Channel from owning too many radio stations or media outlets in the same market, some people went bonkers claiming it was going to mess up the way free speech is handled. A small group owns the majority of outlets that disseminate information and/or entertainment. This allows these corporations to squelch, change, or decide what messages you and I get to hear. In effect this eliminates the old, "Don't like it? Change the channel," argument, because the next channel, owned by the same company, is doing the exact same thing. The sanest argument for capitalism I ever heard came from Rudy Senior at Rudy Junior's bachelor party. He argued that a free market will, eventually over time, reflect the morality, and truth of the society that uses it. Example: Bob hates slavery. Company X produces a cola using slaves. Bob stops buying X-Cola. Cindy loves slavery. She buys X-Cola everyday. Eventually, the Bob's and Cindy's of the world decide whether or not X-Cola can stay in business. If X-Cola, or any other private company owns ALL of the cola's, how will the market decide what is moral, indecent, and just plain silly?
